original_body_lines: Sri Lanka’s external sector continued to strengthen in August 2025, as the current account maintained its streak of monthly surpluses.
The merchandise trade deficit narrowed in August 2025 compared to August 2024, reflecting a higher growth in exports than imports.

Vehicle imports, including both personal and commercial vehicles, amounted to US dollars 249 million in August 2025, bringing the total vehicle imports of US dollars 918 million in the first eight months of 2025.
The terms of trade deteriorated in August 2025 compared to August 2024, as import prices increased at a faster pace than export prices.

The services sector net inflows increased by 2.3 per cent year-on-year to US dollars 2.7 billion during January-August 2025, despite a modest decline recorded in August 2025 compared to the corresponding period of 2024.

Tourist arrivals reached 198,235 in August 2025, reflecting a growth of 20.4 per cent compared to August 2024. Tourist earnings for the month of August were estimated at US dollars 259 million.1 Cumulative tourist earnings during January-August 2025 were estimated at US dollars 2.3 billion, slightly higher than the US dollars 2.1 billion recorded in the corresponding period of 2024.

Workers’ remittances recorded a year-on-year growth of 17.9 per cent to US dollars 681 million in August 2025, thereby sustaining the positive momentum that has been evident in recent months, with cumulative remittances during the first eight months of the year recording a growth of 19.3 per cent compared to the corresponding period of the previous year.

Foreign investments in the government securities market continued to record a net inflow in August 2025, while the foreign investments in the Colombo Stock Exchange (CSE), covering both primary and secondary markets, recorded a net outflow during the month.

Gross official reserves (GOR), including the swap facility with the People’s Bank of China (PBOC), slightly increased by end August 2025 to around US dollars 6.2 billion, amidst continuous debt servicing.
The depreciation of the Sri Lanka rupee against the US dollar in the nine months ending September 2025 was 3.3 per cent.
